In the textile arts, a 'motif' (also called a block or square) is a smaller
element in a much larger work. In knitting and crochet, motifs are made one at a
time and joined together to create larger works such as afghan blankets or
shawls. A good example of a motif is the granny square. Motifs may be varied or
rotated for contrast and variety, or to create new shapes, as with 'quilt
blocks' in quilts and quilting. Contrast with motifless crazy quilting.

Motifs can be any size, but usually all the motifs in any given work are the
same size. The patterns and stitches used in a motif may vary greatly, but there
is almost always some unifying element, such as texture, stitch pattern, or
colour, which gives the finished piece more aesthetic appeal. Motifs may
commemorate events or convey information or political slogans. For example the
individual blocks of the AIDS Memorial Quilt, the possible Quilts of the
Underground Railroad, and the "54-40 or Fight" quilt
block. "[http://earlywomenmasters.net/quilts/f/54_40/index.html 54-40 or
Fight]", Antique Geometric Quilt Designs.
